DOC.HEAD: Report: Many Armed Forces Recruiters Use Fraud to Sell the Service
DOC.TEXT: Military recruiters are resorting to fraud as they try to meet quotas and sell the armed forces to a shrinking pool of applicants, according to a published report. Interviews with former recruiters and documents and statistics obtained through the Freedom of Information Act show that recruiters are luring prospects with promises that cannot be kept, The Hartford Courant reported Sunday. The recruiters enlisted unqualified recruits by helping them fake educational credentials, cheat on aptitude tests and conceal criminal records and medical problems that could otherwise disqualify them, the newspaper said. Overall in the 1988 fiscal year, the Army, Navy, Air Force and Marines investigated a total of 4,128 allegations of fraudulent recruiting. The four services substantiated 701 of the allegations and disciplined 992 recruiters _ about 7 percent of the total recruiting force. There are slightly more than 14,000 recruiters, according to figures supplied by the services. In addition to attracting recruits, the system is supposed to screen applicants, requiring them to pass aptitude tests and physical examinations and to undergo police checks. But one in seven recruits doesn't make it through the first year of service and one in three never finishes the term of enlistment. The cost to taxpayers is hundreds of millions of dollars each year, the newspaper said. ``Every time we recruit somebody that doesn't make it through a first term and we have to replace them, it costs us $18,000,'' said Wayne S. Sellman, the civilian director of the Pentagon office responsible for recruiting policy. More than 42,000 of the 294,000 volunteers recruited by the Pentagon during 1988 were discharged before the end of their first year. Using Sellman's $18,000 figure, the cost of replacing them would be more than $750 million.
